Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <1112> Thanks. i  had no idea hashes could be anything other than completely different when a small input changes.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> there are many many many types of hashes

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> each one is usually designed for some use cases

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> SHA256 is really bad at some things, like being fast

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> That is on purpose, because that is a feature for some use cases

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> SHA256 is very bad at keeping small changes in input from making small changes in output. That would be a bug for malware analysis people

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> But that is a feature for other use cases

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> The theory of hash functions is a large math subfield

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Some are mostly good for implementing datastructures, but not good for cryptography

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> some are fast, some are slow. Some optimized for 8/16bit, others for 64bit

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @1112 here are a few: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_hash_functions

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <1112> I noticed on Panopticlick it lists system fonts, and the fonts i add aren't listed. 

I could never figure out why the fonts i installed didn't become listed as System Fonts. But it looks like these small differences probably don't matter anyways.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> most systems don't even use a hash, they collect every bit of data about you

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and use evercookies, giving your browser a unique id

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> these "evercookies" can use normal cookies, and also newer HTML5 features like `localStorage` to store unique id's of you

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and lots of other sneaky things

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> every web tracking/marketing company already does this stuff

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> clearing your cookies all the time, and localStorage, is a reasonable defense, to the tracking issue

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> the issue of being uniquely identifiable, that means you should emulate the config of a very common browser variant

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> i am sure there are "red team" browsers that lie about everything

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> useragent, XxY resolution, everything

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> because each of those things is a datapoint, i have collected

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> language, timezone

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> everything is a datapoint that can be monetized

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Allowing websites to run arbitrary code via JS on our local computers was a really bad idea

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> But now we are here, and need to deal with it.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <1112> My goal is to blend in. Begin with BleachBit and CCleaner then build a profile based on time zone, updated browser, resolution, MAC address, fonts, user name, computer name. Different profiles for different things. Keep all cookies. I can't be sure any one of those things actually do anything but it's not much trouble trying.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it's easy to leak the username of the current account, be weary of that metadata ðŸ™‚

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> use a worthless account name like "user"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> https://www.ft.com/content/ca95d640-f0b6-11e9-ad1e-4367d8281195

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> `Fidelity rolls out cryptocurrency custody business`

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> a bit of good news for our industry

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> custody biz => big money flows into cryptocoins

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> @1112  I don't recommend BleachBit or CCleaner.  Hackers have put Trojans in CCleaner, in the past.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> https://eraser.heidi.ie/

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> For overwriting, I'd use Eraser, and set it on 7 overwrites, or above.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> If it were me, I'd start from the ground up. So first, I'd harden my OS & modify my Network settings. This will secure your environment.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> __
And then, I'd choose a browser. The first thing to do with it, is to modify the about:config, and limit the data leakage and the browser from calling back to the home server as much as possible.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> I'd download an add-on, like NoScript to limit the websites from executing shit that would reveal your identity. And I'd find an add-on, like an LSO Cookie Manager, that is constantly deleting the super cookie in c:/users/x/appdata/roaming/browser

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> __
I'd use this as my daily browser. 
If I needed a more secure browser for something, I'd run a Live OS, like Tails.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <1112> There are different approaches. I'm just trying to create Alice, Bob, Charlie and let them be normal trackable folks. The BleachBit is to delete the Canvas or flash cookie, or whatever CCleaner doesn't get.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> What I was saying is, is that those apps have a documented history of having malware in them, and infecting millions of users

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> I have used them and I like what they do.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> But after they were revealed to have Trojans, I decided to put more focus on hardening the operation system.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> __
If you want to be like Bob, Steve and Amy then just run a normal browser with very few modifications to the settings.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> Lol some guys don't get that installing specific privacy add-ons, within the browser, only makes u stand out

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <1112> Sure, can go hardcore like that. Imagine Alice reads conspiracy stuff, Bob buys cigar, and Charlie logs into my banks. But nobody who buys cigars logs into my bank stuff. That kind of deal.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> I've tried to do this actually.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> You can't use the same browser, or browser type, for each user

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> Its hard

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> Sounds fun

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <1112> There's only firefox and chrome, and IE is not working on many things. So gotta rely on resolution, time zone, other things.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <1112> Not gonna fool NSA but some tracking algo will have to work extra hard to connect.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> Trident & Gecko based browsers

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> Which ones are you thinking of using?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <1112> Now that i look into it there's a lot of browsers. So far i only use Firefox and Chrome and IE. Using something else might be like wearing a skimask in public hahah.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> There are a lot, but they share the same base.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> Trident & Gecko

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> Chrome, Firefox, Brave, Opera, Internet Explorer

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <1112> Thanks. not looking to turn HUSH chat into a topic on this but it could help like-minded people.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> Well I was discussing it with you, bc I think crypto privacy tech, will try to make use of what computer privacy software has attempted to make work in the past 10-15 years

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> this seems like a relevant discussion so far

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> HushLists potential is so immense

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> Newsletter subscriber lists, have always been an issue. For decades, maybe centuries

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> everything you are saying about confusing things that track web requests, I think about from the perspective of Hush transactions being tracked by ITM-style stuff. It's all very related, just happen to be different software stacks

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> When I starting to read the ITM attack, and then what we have discussed about metadata, I feel like I'm in 2008

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> And I'm trying to secure my data, just on my laptop

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> I mean, look at email subscriber lists.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> For example, who gets the TOR newsletter

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> That is something very important that you wouldn't want to be leaked.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> never heard of it

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> In the past or even now, when you are a group trying to maintain anon, but you need to communicate--you need a way to get in contact with each other

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> yes

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> HushList aims to help some of those use cases

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> Exactly

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and you can use the memo field on any chain, right now, in simple ways

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> HushList is all about unlocking more advanced use cases

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> Such as..

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> all the ones described in the hushlist whitepaper

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> Memo field is our bread and butter

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and various others ðŸ™‚

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> Thinking about metadata leakage, it's crazy to avoid the leakage, you just send 0.001 to 3 unused addresses

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> i wouldn't say it's as simple as that, but yes, things of that nature, if done correctly, can protect one's privacy

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it must be automated to be done correctly

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> I'm trying to tie my knowledge of desktop privacy etc, to crypto.. in terms of what is possible and what is just asanine

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <1112> Currently, if two people chat in Silent Dragon, does each message cost 0.0001 HUSH? And what is the lag between messages?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> Like for example, using a few datasets, that are always sending out random data to minimize linkage or revealing identity

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> miners decide which fees to accept

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> in practice, this means you can use some fee=0 each block, but might not get xtn confirmed

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> even so, the memo field doesn't really care about confs or even notarization

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> so, really, it's how fast your node syncs it's mempool with the node that sends it

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> very often, within minutes or even a few seconds if they are peers

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> by default, it costs 0.0001 HUSH per memo, and you can change that in SD GUI for each xtn

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> a few fee=0 are fine, but miner have code to ignore them

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> So I am just telling you, it cannot be abused

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Miners are not that dumb ðŸ™‚

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> I read the other day, it only takes identifying & linking 50 addresses to deanon, 90% of an entire blockchain.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> Some blockchains

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Crypto99> I believe this was Bitcoin.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> basically no privacy there
